title: Before 1 January 2021, will Tesla release an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights?
preds:
I spent a long time in bucket 1, now I'll spend the rest of the time in bucket two. A price increase on July 1 would imply the feature is availbale July 1 and later. Perhaps the revenue from the feature will be booked in Q3 instead of Q2. If you are curious:
https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-full-self-driving-price-increase-july-1/

Edit: hedging more aggressively. In theory, this question is resolved. Some drivers are driving the beta version of this already... yet for official resolution I imagine we are waiting on a system-wide update.
That said, EM hinted at a price hike 1 July.
So I will say that an official roll-out is slated and he is expecting a jump in demand. Going hard on the $1k price hike date while hedging against a retroactive resolution. https://teslascope.com/teslapedia/software/2020.12.11.1

Well if we are talking about the "Full Self Driving" update, we now have a price hike date.
But hey, to those of you saying, "wait, wasn't this resolved in March?"
I'm with you:
"
FSD works with the car's Autopilot suite and includes a number of features, including automatic lane changes, parallel and perpendicular parking assist, the bring-the-car-to-me summon feature, Navigate on Autopilot highway driving assistance and most recently, ***automatic traffic light and stop sign control***. The next bit of software in the FSD suite will allow the car to automatically steer on city streets, as well.
" I'm going rogue on this one. https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/tesla-full-self-driving-price-increase-elon-musk/
https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a32319055/tesla-software-update-stop-signs-lights/

Right, our dear friend... Ambiguity. 
I suppose it is irrational to *presume* the interpretation of the question - so yes, I am hedging against whether it is deemed that "the future is now" but still holding out for the true intention lending itself to a holiday release of a wider feature suite. I don't pretend to understand Brannigan's Law, I merely enforce it.

FWIW: Still waiting on a clarification or "ruling" promised by GJP about the following (as a possible resolution for this question). I will follow-up again shortly, but the lack of a ruling or clarification makes me start thinking about 'hedging' my forecast a little bit: "In a note sent to a group of Tesla owners who were picked to test the stop light and sign recognition feature, the company said it can be used with the Traffic Aware Cruise Control or Autosteer systems. The feature will slow the car whenever it detects a traffic light, including those that are green or blinking yellow. It will notify the driver of its intent to slow down and stop, and drivers must push down the gear selector and press the accelerator pedal to confirm that it’s safe to proceed." https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2020/04/28/tesla-feature-allows-cars-automatically-stop-traffic-lights/3038976001/

I am loosing my nerve on this one. The beta release will provide lots of passenger miles of new data to help train the neural networks for the full release. Given that the neural networks can continue to train on additional data, I would expect periodic updates throughout the feature's life. The incentive to full release is that would release funds to be booked as revenue that have been accruing since the feature was first sold.
Ot has been announced by Elon Musk that it will be available before year end. It may be used as part of a strategy to get sales in an economic downturn.

Announcements are out that a beta version was part of the 2020.12.6 software release in the US [1,2,3] on 4/24 [4]. It appears it was announced as part of the Q1 earnings call [3]. Like @Ewell_Gregoor, I am wondering the specificity of the question. It seems this beta release does not count either since it is not a full release or that it isn't "navigating" traffic lights. I am going to assume it is because this is still in beta and not a full release. A full release will come sometime later this year, once there is enough data to ensure safety. [1] https://electrek.co/2020/04/24/tesla-autopilot-traffic-light-and-stop-sign-control-feature/
[2] https://www.digitaltrends.com/cars/tesla-autopilot-stop-signs-traffic-lights/
[3] https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-autopilot-traffic-light-update-secrets/
[4] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1vdCt-toHxtSxGqNgOu9Fngl1-01DfnZn-RklDj_IdHc/htmlview

I am now questioning the ambiguity of the question.  `Traffic lights, stop signs, road markings and wheelie bins are all shown when you access the new feature, the car will slow down for a red light if a car is in front of you, however it will currently allow you to run a red light if you are the first car`.  What constitutes as navigating lights? Does this mean total control, or is slowing down but requiring the driver to make the final decision navigating? For me the question should be resolved. But i am decreasing my forecast due to the ambiguity. If we are waiting for an update that can fully stop at lights without needing driver intervention, it wont be for a long time

It appears the update is available, in Europe the update has been detected.
See update below  https://dapplife.com/tesla-ota-2020-12-11-2-software-update-starting-to-roll-out-8047

If I were Elon I would want to release a sign/ light recognition update when the lighting was perfect and the feature would have the best chance of being successful. That's the summer, not in the winter or wetter weather. Pre July 1 and under current covid conditions I'm not sure many people will care and that sentiment might carry through all of 2020
It's going to be difficult to develop new features with COVID-19 going on. Plus Elon has a history of making promises he can't keep.

The person (or machine) who tells the operator of any kind of vehicle what to do to stay on course and out of trouble is a navigator.  If Tesla has a program that does this, it is navigating.  If it actually slows the vehicle down, it is doing even better than navigating.  If the nice people who wrote this question meant the program had to have full operating control of the vehicle, they should have said so.  Words have meanings.

Assuming the technology is ready this year, Tesla will most likely be motivated to roll it out late, to have people in the streets testing it and to avoid having its marketing efforts shadowed by the virus.  The main value for Tesla in this feature will be the marketing and subsequent investments that it will get, which the company will need in the post-COVID-19 economy, but rolling it out when people are at home and worried about the virus would not accomplish the desired publicity. On the other hand, they did promise "L4 automation" by this year to investors, so they will be pushing to release it before year end.

Some more details re traffic light navigation from a 4/28/20 USA Today article (linked): "In a note sent to a group of Tesla owners who were picked to test the stop light and sign recognition feature, the company said it can be used with the Traffic Aware Cruise Control or Autosteer systems. The feature will slow the car whenever it detects a traffic light, including those that are green or blinking yellow. It will notify the driver of its intent to slow down and stop, and drivers must push down the gear selector and press the accelerator pedal to confirm that it’s safe to proceed." Maintaining forecast for now, but may need a ruling from this question's admins. as to whether this new feature basically 'qualifies', as described above.  (I.e., as an Autopilot feature designed to navigate traffic lights.) FWIW, I think it generally does, but will now request a clarification. https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2020/04/28/tesla-feature-allows-cars-automatically-stop-traffic-lights/3038976001/

Following @jayb here [1,2]. Let's see if it is accepted as resolution or if we get a clarification. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1022692
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1023429

More news articles reporting that Tesla is now rolling out a new version of Autopilot to some (non-test fleet) owners that " ...will allow (their vehicles) to see and respond to traffic lights and stop signs". https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2020/04/27/tesla-autopilot-automatically-stop-traffic-lights-signs/ https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/27/21238637/tesla-cars-traffic-light-stop-sign-control-feature-self-driving

Below: Three linked articles from recent days, claiming that Tesla's latest Autopilot update (2020.12.6) now being released (to some owners) "...includes an update to Autopilot that enable vehicles to automatically react to traffic lights and stop signs". One of the articles indicates that the feature (though) being released to the "wider fleet"..."..is still in beta".  FWIW: Submitting this latest info. to GJP for question-resolution consideration, but not forecasting 100% yet ('before July 1') until I get more information. https://electrek.co/2020/04/24/tesla-autopilot-traffic-light-and-stop-sign-control-feature/ https://teslamotorsclub.com/blog/2020/04/25/teslas-software-update-includes-traffic-light-and-stop-sign-control/ https://www.engadget.com/tesla-traffic-light-stop-sign-autopilot-183724262.html

If this comes out this year, it won't be until COVID calms down slightly. The movement of this feature to testing (https://tiresandparts.net/news/parts/tesla-working-on-new-autopilot-update-to-help-recognize-traffic-lights/) doesn't seem to indicate how well it is working.

Moving forecast a little closer to the 'crowd' for now, though an update of Autopilot that recognizes traffic signals has reportedly already been released to Tesla's "early access fleet" (users). https://tiresandparts.net/news/parts/tesla-working-on-new-autopilot-update-to-help-recognize-traffic-lights/

Elon Musk has a track record of over promising and underdelivering. Secondly software development itself is notoriously tricky and very costly. Auto Pilot features are very hard to deliver safely and are hard even by software standards.

Taking an even more positive stance due to [1,2] Hattip to @jayb and @Oriondirect! [1] https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-autopilot-traffic-light-stop-sign-controls-eap/
[2] https://electrek.co/2020/04/16/tesla-vehicles-drop-off-park-themselves/
I have decided that I have to be positive about something, why not believe in Elon?

Linked source claims Autopilot traffic light feature is "currently in testing in (the) early access program" and "is expected to launch in the U.S. in the next few weeks".  
https://electrek.co/2020/04/16/tesla-vehicles-drop-off-park-themselves/

I’m under the impression that Tesla’s abilities to come up with smart solutions in the car industry are dramatically over estimated. A modern car is a complex machine and a lot of experience goes into it. And for example the Chinese with all their engineering prowess are not able to simply copy a Porsche or BMW. And Tesla operates under the restrictions of the US capital market regime.
Changed forecast based on [1]. Still sceptical if it's actually going to happen. [1] https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1246206799973191680?lang=de

From my research it looks as though Tesla has the technology in place already to launch the feature at short notice. However, common sense dictates that the feature go through rigorous testing before it is launched. This article says that the feature should be launched in the US within a matter of weeks: https://electrek.co/2020/04/03/tesla-release-autopilot-intersection-navigation-weeks-us-months-worldwide/.  My initial reaction was that it would be difficult to launch the feature this year owing to regulatory requirements. However, I now believe that regulatory approval shouldn’t be an issue insofar as the US is concerned. Tesla has released various autonomous features for its vehicles in the past and US regulatory approval doesn’t appear to have been an issue. I found an article which says “… as long as Tesla (or any automaker) plans to upgrade its FMVSS-compliant vehicles with software alone, or even hardware like processors that aren't regulated by FMVSS, that update wouldn't require any form of regulatory approval..” (https://www.thedrive.com/tech/29338/what-are-the-regulatory-barriers-to-full-self-driving). Regulatory approval may be an issue in some parts of the world but the question doesn’t require the feature to have been released in more than one location - the US will suffice.  I don’t think Covid-19 will prevent Tesla from launching the feature this year. As indicated above, it seems as though most of the work has already been done. A lot of the work needing to be done is in relation to software which is relatively easy to do remotely. I can’t rule out that, if the situation in the US gets really bad, it may cause a slight delay, hence why I think there is an outside chance that it will be launched between July and September.

This sounds promising but Musk has burned me too many times with his optimistic timelines.although it could work well in current situation with greatly reduced traffic in most of world. ;)
https://electrek.co/2020/03/30/tesla-self-driving-traffic-light-stop-sign-explained-leaked-manual/
Going back to a more optimistic stance. Will the virus slow the team down or not?

April 3, Musk texted that it will be released in the next few weeks, in the US and WW in the upcoming months.
While I disagree with this product, and think this is horrible, bad idea, I can't let my personal feelings cloud the forecast.    Musk is a creditable actor, and while he often slips on schedules his desires usually happen.

Musk is saying they are soon, but he said this in 2018.  Can either see it coming soon or not at all this year https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-will-hike-price-semi-autonomous-full-self-driving-package-2020-4?r=US&IR=T
Ok, I am weakening my resolve, by just a little. The bits are aligned, just when will they be released?
feeling confident it will happen sooner rather than later. Elon Musk is a mad man.
Elon Musk is a mad man
Current distractions will preclude concentration on the issue or regulatory attention
This technology is still a decade away.

Linked 4/3/20 articles claim: "Tesla is aiming to release the ability for Autopilot to navigate intersections in just weeks in the US, but it will take months for other markets." https://electrek.co/2020/04/03/tesla-release-autopilot-intersection-navigation-weeks-us-months-worldwide/ https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-autopilot-fsd-traffic-light-ota-update/
10 mins, said to be released "within a few weeks", but musk tends to be bullish with his predictions. Unlinkey to be last qtr of the year or beyond as he would not be saying a few weeks.
Got to feel optimistic about something, right.

Following @Coastal and @jayb lead I'll vote optimistically that TSLA can do this in 2020. With a lot fewer people on the road the next few months what a great time to beta test it. I mean how hard can it be to pick out a green or red light in your 180 degree field of view moving at 40MpH in the driving rain and get at least two cameras to agree?

Musk first floated the idea back in 2018 (1), Musk said in a tweet in December 2018 that we would soon be able to put the Teslar in the garage without doing anything.  27 months later and its had it first successful test - which is progress, but at a slow rate. Musk liked to commit to challenges and give specific time frames.  Im giving an outside view that 27 months have passed since the idea. The answers are 3 months apart. So 27/3 = 9% per section of yes and 73% for no.  Other Factors - 
If it was imminent, i would expect him to say. He likes to state time frames, like he has with SpaceX. Therefore ill drop July 1st by 5%. 

Something just tells me that whilst all the evidence points to no, the silence between 2018 and then now with a video of it in action. Whilst not imminent, it wont be far away.  Therefore i will increase the chances later in the year  https://www.engadget.com/2018-12-09-tesla-navigate-on-autopilot-traffic-light-testing.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAH5h2BTq7gxXY3nGQwx8UR3RROSXwFur2-_Cm7uW9rvT5z65u_izeEMXzOHe1zCy8dqTwGYmvxljEIWpS44fy7xV4GycHBif43HGe1nFZFW9tFYC3Raidl_6mPFO-aB1ZhinROanBpB4sReZRnGSTZc75QuPhmfCCKsvU-xCCysn

Originally I followed @jayb and @Coastal in their line of argumentation [1, 2]. However, I went with the crowd in the end. I'm not a close follower of Tesla and don't know if they have a specific update schedule or if they just push updates as soon as they consider them ready. Does someone know more? Another issue concerns the regulatory requirements. Are there any regulations in place that will require Tesla to get government approval before rolling out a new feature like that? There are already voices that warn about a careless implementation [3]. Musk has retweeted [4]. Does he usually retweet anything that'll be provided in a soon update?
According to [5] traffic light navigation should be released later in the year. Following the Twitter discussion [6], I'm very sceptic that it'll be implemented in the coming months, maybe not even this year. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1007262
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1007533
[3] https://www.forbes.com/sites/lanceeliot/2020/03/30/coming-release-of-tesla-autopilot-red-light-auto-stopping-could-trigger-a-self-driving-downward-spiral/
[4] https://twitter.com/thirdrowtesla/status/1243297346059816960
[5] https://electrek.co/2020/03/04/tesla-self-driving-features-march-city-street-autopilot/
[6] https://twitter.com/thirdrowtesla/status/1243297346059816960

Musk has only "expressed interest" in this, which may mean he'll leave the pros alone to make it work.   If he'd absolutely promised it, there'd be less than a zero chance since he'd feel the need to mux about in the process.  Still, this is harder than it sounds.

Tesla already released red-light awareness in March 2020 to EAP owners.
https://electrek.co/2020/03/26/tesla-autopilot-automatically-stop-red-light-video/
The country will be recovering from or may still be in a depression.

Possibly speculative 3/30/20 story (linked below)  asserting that: "..Tesla is about to release a new update (to its Autopilot) that will result in...Autopilot, under its Full Self-Driving package, reacting to traffic light and stop signs".  Article indicates such a release would be "...to its “early access fleet,” a group of owners who beta test new software update from Tesla." 
(..It's not totally clear to me if a limited 'beta' release would count for this question.. It's also currently unclear to me exactly when the next Tesla Autopilot update is to be released.)  (LInk:) https://electrek.co/guides/tesla-autopilot/ Another 3/30/20 article asserting essentially the same thing (i.e., feature will be in the next Autopilot update:) 
https://cleantechnica.com/2020/03/27/coming-tesla-autopilot-update-to-include-auto-stopping-at-red-lights-stop-signs-leaked-video/. 
Another: https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a31947908/video-shows-tesla-autopilot-stopping-a-model-3-at-a-stoplight/ Pending more info. starting the forecast off with a 'sooner rather than later' bias for now.
Tesla may think they can but government regulators will slow the progress to make sure of safety.
The focus is more on different technology currently. The roll out of new technology is now somewhat altered.
